video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Snapmaker 2.0 falls into the "tricked out 3D printer" category, along with the diode modules you install in your 3D printer.
Again no M1 on the list, which is still a viable choice for crafters
Snapmaker Ray 40 is in the wrong category, it's an open frame with optional enclosure.

The open frame category is designed for a low upfront cost and not meant to be used as they are but be equipped with accessories later.

The "desktop diode" category has branched in two directions: one is the crafter category (M1, M1 Ultra, WeCreat, Flux Ador, Aura, Spark) and one is hobby/workshop (S1, Falcon2 Pro, Roly, Genmitsu S8). The crafter machines are getting multifunctional with printing/blade cutting modules, while the hobby ones focus on lasers.

Instead of having an always ticked "enclosure" column, you should add important parameters missing from your sheet:
* how the focus works: by moving the module or bed - as this limits functionality, you can't easily do curved surface processing when the whole bed has to move up and down
* rotary attachment support - out of the box, with optional riser base, etc.
* pass through / removable bottom plate

BTW as far as I know WeCreat somehow shot off xTool (ex employees?) - their software is basically a clone of xCS 1.x.
BTW2 you could have waited with this until the P2S review.

video_title: Laser Companies Are Lying To You
comment_text: It's not the total watts, but pulse width, pulse rate, M2 value to maximize your total energy at the focus. So if 40 watt has 100 um spot and the 20 watt has 40 um spot. The 20 watt is going to crush the 40 watt. Also anything over 0.5 watts is a class 4 laser.

video_title: Laser Companies Are Lying To You
comment_text: The more diodelasers are stacked, the more semi-transparent mirrors the beam has to go through and thus the more scattered the beam gets (polution in the mirrors). So the beam isn't as crisp as with one laser (i.e. lower power)

comment_text: I have an Atomstack 48w.   It cuts and engraved great.  With lasers the real issue is speed- how fast can you cut and move to the next.  I believe the continuous improvement on diode lasers will push time lasers down in price.  I’m just impressed I live in a time where you can have a laser in your workshop!
